elements.content: A recyclable and magnetic nanocomposite catalyst (IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1) was synthesized via grafting ionic liquid (IL) [AEMIm]­BF4 into magnetically functionalized metal–organic framework Fe3O4@HKUST-1 in a water–ethanol media. The properties of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were fully characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, electron microscopy, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, nitrogen adsorption–desorption, density-functional theory, and a magnetic property measurement system. IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 showed high activity in the solvent-free cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides under mild conditions. Furthermore, the catalyst can be easily separated from the reaction mixture, and the recycled catalyst maintained high performance for several cycles. The synergistic effect of the Lewis acid and base sites in IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 contributes to its greater reactivity than individual IL or HKUST-1.

The properties of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were fully characterized by powder X-ray diffraction, electron microscopy, Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy, nitrogen adsorption-desorption, density-functional theory, and a magnetic property measurement system. IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 showed high activity in the solvent-free cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides under mild conditions. Furthermore, the catalyst can be easily separated from the reaction mixture, and the recycled catalyst maintained high performance for several cycles. The synergistic effect of the Lewis acid and base sites in IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 contributes to its greater reactivity than individual IL or HKUST-1.

elements.content: Chemists have been interested in developing sustainable and ecofriendly materials for various applications. Lately, significant attention has been focused on carbon dioxide (CO2) utilization. The continually rising atmospheric CO2 level has led to devastating environmental damage such as climate change. The potential use of CO2 as a cheap, nontoxic, and abundant C1 building block for organic synthesis has been studied. For example, the catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to form cyclic carbonates has been considered as a green approach to utilize CO2 in terms of atom economy. Furthermore, the cyclic carbonates show versatile application such as solvents, electrolytes, lubricants, synthetic building blocks, fine chemicals, and monomers for polymer synthesis.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Chemists have been interested in developing sustainable and ecofriendly materials for various applications. Lately, significant attention has been focused on carbon dioxide (CO2) utilization. The continually rising atmospheric CO2 level has led to devastating environmental damage such as climate change. The potential use of CO2 as a cheap, nontoxic, and abundant C1 building block for organic synthesis has been studied. For example, the catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides to form cyclic carbonates has been considered as a green approach to utilize CO2 in terms of atom economy. Furthermore, the cyclic carbonates show versatile application such as solvents, electrolytes, lubricants, synthetic building blocks, fine chemicals, and monomers for polymer synthesis.

elements.content: The reactivity between epoxides and CO2 is limited by the high thermodynamic and kinetic stability of CO2. Therefore, a large energy supply and harsh reaction conditions are required for CO bond cleavage. Although various homogeneous catalysts such as organic bases, ionic liquids (ILs), and metal salts have been shown to catalyze CO2 cycloaddition reactions with epoxides, the complicated product separation process and harsh reaction condition have limited their industrial application. Metal–organic framework (MOF) based heterogeneous catalysts have also been studied in the area of CO2 adsorption and utilization. However, the MOF catalyzed CO2 cycloaddition reaction with epoxides still requires high reaction temperature and pressure. In 2018, we synthesized an acid–base bifunctional heterogeneous catalyst by immobilizing the carboxyl-functionlized ionic liquid into MIL-101-NH2; the catalyst showed great reactivity even under mild conditions (91% yield at 1.3 MPa, 120 °C without additive). The improved reactivity arises from the coorperative activation of CO2 and expoxides, between the Brønsted acid (−COOH) in the ionic liquid and the Lewis base (−NH2) in MIL-101-NH2. However, filtration or centrifugation is still required for product separation, thus limiting its application in industry-scale reactions. To overcome this shortcoming, one of the potential strategies is to introduce magnetic material into MOFs; magnetic materials have been successfully combined with many materials. In order to achieve efficient catalytic activity, the choice of ionic liquid was carefully examined. Previous literature suggests that imidazolium ILs possess a fine chemical stability and efficient catalytic activity for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxide. The tetrafluoroborate [BF4]− anion demonstrates high reactivity; the in situ formed anionic species ([BF4–CO2]−) is found to be more reactive for binding with activated epoxides. Moreover, its low viscosity is desired for confining ILs into the pores of MOFs.

elements.content: In this work, a magnetically recoverable heterogeneous catalyst (denoted as IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1) was constructed via a facile method. The catalyst combines the advantages of recyclable magnetic materials, active ionic liquids, and porous metal–organic framework materials, and it shows efficient catalytic performance for cyclic carbonate synthesis under mild conditions.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Fe3O4 nanoparticles (20 nm) were purchased from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Limited Company. Cupric nitrate trihydrate (Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O) was purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Limited Company. Ethanol, epoxide, and ammonium hydroxide were purchased from Tianjin Kemiou Chemical Reagent Company. Trimesic acid (H3BTC) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin biochemical technology Limited Company. Carbon dioxide (99.99%) was purchased from Dalian GuangMing Special Gas Products Limited Company. 1-Aminoethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (IL:[AEMIm]BF4) was purchased from green chemistry and catalysis, LICP, CAS.

elements.content: The support Fe3O4@HKUST-1 was synthesized from a known procedure with modifications. Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3: A 1.5 mL solution of ammonium hydroxide and ethanol (VNH4OH:VEtOH = 1:5) was added to a mixture of Fe3O4 nanoparticles (0.26 g) and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.30 g) in 30 mL of EtOH. After stirring 24 h at 60 °C, the product was collected by filtration and washed with water/EtOH for ten times. Fe3O4@HKUST-1: Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3 (50 mg, dried under vacuum) was added to a solution of 5 mL of ethanol, 2 mL of H2O, and 55 mg of H3BTC; the mixture was stirred for 12 h at 60 °C. The product was isolated with a magnet and washed with water/EtOH for 10 times. Followed by drying at 120 °C overnight in a vacuum oven, the product was obtained as a black powder.

elements.content: Thirty milligrams of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and 10 mg of [AEMIm]­BF4 (IL) were dispersed in 30 mL of EtOH, the mixture was thoroughly mixed on a rotary-evaporator in a 45 °C water bath until the solvent was removed. The solids were collected with a magnet and washed with ethanol for 5 times (10 mL each), after being dried in a 70 °C vacuum oven, the product named IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 was isolated as a green-grayish solid. The simplified synthetic route is shown in .
elements.clean_text:
Catalyst

Thirty milligrams of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and 10 mg of [AEMIm]BF4 (IL) were dispersed in 30 mL of EtOH, the mixture was thoroughly mixed on a rotary-evaporator in a 45 °C water bath until the solvent was removed. The solids were collected with a magnet and washed with ethanol for 5 times (10 mL each), after being dried in a 70 °C vacuum oven, the product named IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 was isolated as a green-grayish solid. The simplified synthetic route is shown in .

elements.content: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a JSM-6360LV, and the corresponding mapping was recorded at 15 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken with an AMT camera system. The solid-state structure was obtained from powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Empyrean instrument). Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained from a Bruker-Tenson 27 instrument. The Brunauer–Emmett–Teller surface area was calculated with N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms at −196 °C. The pore volumes were derived from the adsorption branches of isotherms by density functional theory (DFT). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were analyzed using a Kratos Axis ultra XPS spectrometer. Elemental analysis (EA) was measured on vario EL III. The thermogravimetric (TG) curves were measured with a thermal analyzer instrument under N2 flow from 20 to 800 °C. Magnetic properties of samples were studied using a Quantum Design SQUID (MPMS XL-7) magnetometer.
elements.clean_text:
Catalyst Characterization

Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were taken on a JSM-6360LV, and the corresponding mapping was recorded at 15 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were taken with an AMT camera system. The solid-state structure was obtained from powder X-ray diffraction (XRD, Empyrean instrument). Fourier-transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were obtained from a Bruker-Tenson 27 instrument. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller surface area was calculated with N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms at -196 °C. The pore volumes were derived from the adsorption branches of isotherms by density functional theory (DFT). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were analyzed using a Kratos Axis ultra XPS spectrometer. Elemental analysis (EA) was measured on vario EL III. The thermogravimetric (TG) curves were measured with a thermal analyzer instrument under N2 flow from 20 to 800 °C. Magnetic properties of samples were studied using a Quantum Design SQUID (MPMS XL-7) magnetometer.

elements.content: The periodic structure HKUST-1 was intercepted into a representative fragment for calculating the interaction between guest ions (BF4 – or [AMIm]+) and HKUST-1. All calculations were performed using DFT implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). Generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew–Burke–Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional was adopted to handle the exchange–correlation interaction. The frozen-core projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe the ion–electron interactions. The electron wave functions were expanded in a plane-wave basis with a kinetic energy cutoff of 520 eV.
elements.clean_text:
Computational Method

The periodic structure HKUST-1 was intercepted into a representative fragment for calculating the interaction between guest ions (BF4 - or [AMIm]+) and HKUST-1. All calculations were performed using DFT implemented in the Vienna ab initio simulation package (VASP). Generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange-correlation functional was adopted to handle the exchange-correlation interaction. The frozen-core projector augmented wave (PAW) method was used to describe the ion-electron interactions. The electron wave functions were expanded in a plane-wave basis with a kinetic energy cutoff of 520 eV.

IL loading [ mol % ] = N IL * m cat n e p o x i d e * 100 % , NIL (mmol/g): the ionic liquid source loading of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1.

Results and DiscussionCharacterization of Catalyst

To study the composition of new nanocomposite IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, its XRD pattern was recorded (, green) and compared with the starting materials Fe3O4 (, blue), Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3 (, pink), and simulated HKUST-1 (, red). The similarities among the diffraction patterns of simulated HKUST-1, Fe3O4@HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 suggested them to be isostructural crystalline solids. In addition, patterns that correspond to Fe3O4 can be found in Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3, Fe3O4@HKUST, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, which indicated that Fe3O4 was successfully integrated into HKUST-1. Remarkably, compared with crystal diffraction peaks in Fe3O4@HKUST-1, the HKUST-1 crystal diffraction peaks in the IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were weaker and shifted slightly to the left. The small variations in peak intensities between the pristine Fe3O4@HKUST and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 after IL incorporation are attributed to confinement of IL in the HKUST-1 pores, as has previously been shown in the literature. Furthermore, the introduction of IL into the magnetically functionalized HKUST-1 did not affect the crystalline octahedral structure, supported by the images from SEM and TEM (b, c, e, and f). Despite the tiny collapse and coarse crystal surfaces that occur after functionalization and ionic liquid immobilization, they remained overall crystalline. The TEM images (d, e, and f) of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 clearly illustrate that the synthesized material has the characteristic nanocomposite structures that Fe3O4 particles were capsulated within the pores of HKUST-1.

Results and Discussion

Characterization of Catalyst

To study the composition of new nanocomposite IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, its XRD pattern was recorded (, green) and compared with the starting materials Fe3O4 (, blue), Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3 (, pink), and simulated HKUST-1 (, red). The similarities among the diffraction patterns of simulated HKUST-1, Fe3O4@HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 suggested them to be isostructural crystalline solids. In addition, patterns that correspond to Fe3O4 can be found in Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3, Fe3O4@HKUST, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, which indicated that Fe3O4 was successfully integrated into HKUST-1. Remarkably, compared with crystal diffraction peaks in Fe3O4@HKUST-1, the HKUST-1 crystal diffraction peaks in the IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were weaker and shifted slightly to the left. The small variations in peak intensities between the pristine Fe3O4@HKUST and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 after IL incorporation are attributed to confinement of IL in the HKUST-1 pores, as has previously been shown in the literature. Furthermore, the introduction of IL into the magnetically functionalized HKUST-1 did not affect the crystalline octahedral structure, supported by the images from SEM and TEM (b, c, e, and f). Despite the tiny collapse and coarse crystal surfaces that occur after functionalization and ionic liquid immobilization, they remained overall crystalline. The TEM images (d, e, and f) of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 clearly illustrate that the synthesized material has the characteristic nanocomposite structures that Fe3O4 particles were capsulated within the pores of HKUST-1.

elements.content: To further disclose the modified process of composite and immobilization, the FTIR spectra of Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3, Fe3O4/HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 () were studied. As for Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3 (, red), the band at 1515 cm–1 was assigned to the symmetrical stretching vibration of the NO from the NO3 – group. In comparison, the NO corresponding peak was barely observed in the spectrum of Fe3O4/HKUST-1 (, blue); this is attributed to the reaction of trimesic acid (H3TBC) with Cu2(OH)3NO3 during the synthesis of HKUST-1. In addition, several new peaks were detected in the region of 1200–600 cm–1, which were assigned to the deformation vibration of C–H and the skeleton stretching vibration of CC from the aromatic ring in the backbone of HKUST-1. The band corresponding to the CO stretching vibration (1759 cm–1) of the CO2 – group was detected in Fe3O4/HKUST-1 (, blue) and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (, black), indicating the presence of HKUST-1 in both Fe3O4/HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1. Compared to the as-synthesized support of Fe3O4@HKUST-1, a few new peaks were observed in the IL immobilization sample of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1. For example, the appearance of peaks at 1652 and 807 cm–1 was due to the N–H in-plane and out-of-plane bending vibrations of the ammonium functional groups from ionic liquid [AEMIm]­BF4(IL); similarly, the peak at 1588 cm–1 was due to the unsaturated CC stretching of the imidazole functional group. Furthermore, with the introduction of IL, the N–H bending vibration frequency was decreased to 807 cm–1, indicating the interaction between the electron-rich amino group from the IL and unsaturated copper ions in the HKUST-1 framework, thereby forming the N–Cu coordination bond.

elements.content: To recognize the interactions between the IL and Fe3O4@HKUST-1, the XPS survey scans for the N, O, and Cu elements were performed. For IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (a, red), the presence of N element and F element (binding energy (B.E.) at 400 and 685 eV) was detected because of the introduction of [AEMIm]­BF4 ionic liquid. As shown in (b), two characteristic peaks of Cu 2p spectra for Fe3O4/HKUST-1 could be observed at about 932.6 and 952.4 eV, which are assigned to Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2. After Fe3O4@HKUST-1 was modified by [AEMIm]­BF4 ionic liquid, the B.E. of the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 spectrum of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (b, red) shifted downward to 932.3 and 952.0 eV, respectively. Such reduction is presumably due to the interaction of unsaturated copper ions in HKUST-1 with the lone pair electrons from the amino group in [AEMIm]­BF4, which is consistent with the preliminary prediction of FTIR spectra. A slight decrease in the intensity of “shake-up satellite bands” also supports that the ionic liquid was immobilized on the Fe3O4/HKUST-1.

elements.content: The interaction of the IL within MOF pores was further investigated by DFT calculation. The adsorption energy of optimized HKUST-1 with BF4 – or [AMIm]+ was calculated. The calculated adsorption energy of [AMIm]+/HKUST-1 (−3.33 eV) is more significant than that of BF4 –/HKUST-1 (−2.96 eV), indicating a stronger interaction between Cu2+ and -NH2 on [AMIm]+ than with BF4 –. The stability of the interaction is due to the difference of the charge distribution in [AMIm]+ and BF4 –, consistent with the charge density differences presented in . Together with the results from FTIR and XPS, DFT calculation also predicts a Lewis acid and Lewis base interaction between Cu2+ and an amino group, which is one of the driving forces for introducing the IL into the MOF.

elements.content: Nitrogen sorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves for Fe3O4, Fe3O4/HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 are illustrated in . For both Fe3O4/HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, the nitrogen sorption isotherms exhibited an I/IV mixed type isotherm ((a)), suggesting that both as-synthesized samples contain microporous and mesoporous structures. The BET (Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller) surface area and total specific pore volume of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles were found to be 33.7 m2/g and 0.16 cm3/g. In comparison these values were increased to 396.2 m2/g and 0.29 cm3/g in the case of Fe3O4@HKUST-1. The increment primarily originated from the high porosity of HKUST-1. After the incorporation of [AEMIm]­BF4 ionic liquid, BET study revealed a decline in surface area (70.64 m2/g), along with lesser calculated pore volumes (0.14 cm3/g). The reduced surface area and pore volume is due to the occupancy of ionic liquids in the pores of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 support. Moreover, the pore size distribution curves of Fe3O4/HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were calculated by DFT ((b)). In the former material, the microporous distribution centered at about 0.70 and 0.75 nm. As [AEMIm]­BF4 ionic liquid was introduced, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 exhibited a pore size distribution centered at 0.39 nm. The decrease of pore size may be due to incorporation of ionic liquid, which agrees with the results from FT-IR and XPS studies.

elements.content: The thermal property of the material was studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 flow; the results of Fe3O4, HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 are shown in . As expected, Fe3O4 showed great thermal stability, and no significant weight loss was seen up to 800 °C. In the case of HKUST-1, the first weight loss was seen continuously from room temperature to 150 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of water, including the water inside and outside the pores of HKUST-1. A similar weight loss between room temperature to 150 °C was also observed in IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1; however, the ratio of the lost weight was much lesser than HKUST-1, because the initial water molecules were replaced by IL. The second significant weight loss step that started at around 350 °C was probably assigned to the collapse of the HKUST-1 frameworks due to the decomposition of organic components.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were measured by a MPMS magnetometer. It is clear from the room-temperature magnetization curves of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 () that the corresponding saturation magnetizations of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were 49 emu/g and 38 emu/g, respectively. Despite the lower saturation magnetization, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 was readily collected with a magnet from solution (inset of ); this property allows it to be a recyclable and magnetically functionalized catalyst.

elements.content: The catalytic performance of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 in the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides with CO2 (1.3 MPa) was investigated in solvent-free conditions. The cycloaddition reaction did not proceed in the absence of catalyst (, entry 1). Furthermore, Fe3O4 or HKUST-1 was also found to be inactive toward the cycloaddition reaction (entries 2–3). In contrast, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 4) showed an excellent performance in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide; 94% yield was obtained after 2 h at 120 °C under 1.3 MPa CO2. Under the same conditions, the IL alone showed a lower yield of 61% (entry 5). Generally, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 showed better catalytic performance than IL. In the case of epichlorohydrin, the product yield was 88% with IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 6); a lower yield (42%) was obtained with IL (entry 7). Similarly, when epibromohydrin was tested, the corresponding cyclic carbonate was obtained in 82% yield with IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 8) and 40% with IL (entry 9). Experiments were also tested under lower pressure of CO2 (0.1 MPa); a longer reaction time 24 h was required to obtain similar yield (entry 4–9). It is also worth noting magnetic separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture could be easily carried out and reused without significant loss of activity for the cyclization transformation ().

Catalytic Performance

The catalytic performance of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 in the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides with CO2 (1.3 MPa) was investigated in solvent-free conditions. The cycloaddition reaction did not proceed in the absence of catalyst (, entry 1). Furthermore, Fe3O4 or HKUST-1 was also found to be inactive toward the cycloaddition reaction (entries 2-3). In contrast, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 4) showed an excellent performance in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide; 94% yield was obtained after 2 h at 120 °C under 1.3 MPa CO2. Under the same conditions, the IL alone showed a lower yield of 61% (entry 5). Generally, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 showed better catalytic performance than IL. In the case of epichlorohydrin, the product yield was 88% with IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 6); a lower yield (42%) was obtained with IL (entry 7). Similarly, when epibromohydrin was tested, the corresponding cyclic carbonate was obtained in 82% yield with IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 8) and 40% with IL (entry 9). Experiments were also tested under lower pressure of CO2 (0.1 MPa); a longer reaction time 24 h was required to obtain similar yield (entry 4-9). It is also worth noting magnetic separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture could be easily carried out and reused without significant loss of activity for the cyclization transformation ().

elements.content: Based on the experimental observations that the presence of both HKUST-1 and IL is required for effective catalysis, a plausible cycloaddition reaction mechanism catalyzed by the IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 involving the consecutive insertion of carbon dioxide, ring-opening of epoxide, and ring closure of cyclic carbonate is presented in . Initially, the positively charged ammonium ion acts as a Lewis acid to polarize and activate the C–O bond in CO2, followed by the nucleophilic addition of the BF4 – group to the carbon atom of carbon dioxide. Simultaneously, the Lewis acidic ammonium groups and/or remaining Lewis acidic Cu2+ from HKUST-1 can activate the epoxide moiety. Subsequently, the reaction of in situ formed anionic species ([BF4–CO2]−) and epoxide generates an intermediate with a new C–O bond. The intermediate is converted into the final product of cyclic carbonate upon ring-closure reaction and regenerates the catalyst at the same time. Overall, owing to the synergetic role of dual functional active sites offered by IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, the cycloaddition reaction of carbon dioxide was effectively achieved under mild conditions and showed improved reactivity than ionic liquid alone.

Initially, the positively charged ammonium ion acts as a Lewis acid to polarize and activate the C-O bond in CO2, followed by the nucleophilic addition of the BF4 - group to the carbon atom of carbon dioxide. Simultaneously, the Lewis acidic ammonium groups and/or remaining Lewis acidic Cu2+ from HKUST-1 can activate the epoxide moiety. Subsequently, the reaction of in situ formed anionic species ([BF4-CO2]-) and epoxide generates an intermediate with a new C-O bond. The intermediate is converted into the final product of cyclic carbonate upon ring-closure reaction and regenerates the catalyst at the same time. Overall, owing to the synergetic role of dual functional active sites offered by IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, the cycloaddition reaction of carbon dioxide was effectively achieved under mild conditions and showed improved reactivity than ionic liquid alone.

elements.content: In summary, a magnetic recyclable catalyst, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, was synthesized from grafting ionic liquid [AEMIm]­BF4 into porous Fe3O4@HKUST-1 nanocomposite. The catalyst showed excellent yield for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides under mild conditions. Various techniques demonstrated that Fe3O4@HKUST-1 kept its crystalline structure throughout the immobilization process of binding Fe3O4@HKUST-1 with the ionic liquid. The catalyst can be easily recovered using a magnet and reused without significant degradation after five cycles owing to the magnetic properties of Fe3O4@HKUST-1. The merits of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, such as good stability, magnetic recovery, and the relatively easy synthesis procedure, are particularly desirable for CO2 conversion and green industrial chemical processes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, a magnetic recyclable catalyst, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, was synthesized from grafting ionic liquid [AEMIm]BF4 into porous Fe3O4@HKUST-1 nanocomposite. The catalyst showed excellent yield for the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with epoxides under mild conditions. Various techniques demonstrated that Fe3O4@HKUST-1 kept its crystalline structure throughout the immobilization process of binding Fe3O4@HKUST-1 with the ionic liquid. The catalyst can be easily recovered using a magnet and reused without significant degradation after five cycles owing to the magnetic properties of Fe3O4@HKUST-1. The merits of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, such as good stability, magnetic recovery, and the relatively easy synthesis procedure, are particularly desirable for CO2 conversion and green industrial chemical processes.

cln_elements.content: The support Fe3O4@HKUST-1 was synthesized from a known procedure with modifications. Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3: A 1.5 mL solution of ammonium hydroxide and ethanol (VNH4OH:VEtOH = 1:5) was added to a mixture of Fe3O4 nanoparticles (0.26 g) and Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O (0.30 g) in 30 mL of EtOH. After stirring 24 h at 60 °C, the product was collected by filtration and washed with water/EtOH for ten times. Fe3O4@HKUST-1: Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3 (50 mg, dried under vacuum) was added to a solution of 5 mL of ethanol, 2 mL of H2O, and 55 mg of H3BTC; the mixture was stirred for 12 h at 60 °C. The product was isolated with a magnet and washed with water/EtOH for 10 times. Followed by drying at 120 °C overnight in a vacuum oven, the product was obtained as a black powder.
cln_elements.clean_text: The support Fe3O4@HKUST-1 was synthesized from a known procedure with modifications. Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3: A 1.5 mL solution of ammonium hydroxide and ethanol (VNH4OH:VEtOH = 1:5) was added to a mixture of Fe3O4 nanoparticles (0.26 g) and Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O (0.30 g) in 30 mL of EtOH. After stirring 24 h at 60 °C, the product was collected by filtration and washed with water/EtOH for ten times. Fe3O4@HKUST-1: Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3 (50 mg, dried under vacuum) was added to a solution of 5 mL of ethanol, 2 mL of H2O, and 55 mg of H3BTC; the mixture was stirred for 12 h at 60 °C. The product was isolated with a magnet and washed with water/EtOH for 10 times. Followed by drying at 120 °C overnight in a vacuum oven, the product was obtained as a black powder.

cln_elements.content:
Nitrogen sorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves for Fe3O4, Fe3O4/HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 are illustrated in . For both Fe3O4/HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1, the nitrogen sorption isotherms exhibited an I/IV mixed type isotherm ((a)), suggesting that both as-synthesized samples contain microporous and mesoporous structures. The BET (Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller) surface area and total specific pore volume of the Fe3O4 nanoparticles were found to be 33.7 m2/g and 0.16 cm3/g. In comparison these values were increased to 396.2 m2/g and 0.29 cm3/g in the case of Fe3O4@HKUST-1. The increment primarily originated from the high porosity of HKUST-1. After the incorporation of [AEMIm]­BF4 ionic liquid, BET study revealed a decline in surface area (70.64 m2/g), along with lesser calculated pore volumes (0.14 cm3/g). The reduced surface area and pore volume is due to the occupancy of ionic liquids in the pores of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 support. Moreover, the pore size distribution curves of Fe3O4/HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were calculated by DFT ((b)). In the former material, the microporous distribution centered at about 0.70 and 0.75 nm. As [AEMIm]­BF4 ionic liquid was introduced, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 exhibited a pore size distribution centered at 0.39 nm. The decrease of pore size may be due to incorporation of ionic liquid, which agrees with the results from FT-IR and XPS studies.

The elemental analysis was implemented to further investigate the loading amount of the IL over Fe3O4/HKUST-1 (). The structural models of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3, Fe3O4/HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 are shown in to explain the source of nitrogen. It was found that the N element loading amounts of Fe3O4, Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3, Fe3O4/HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were 0.00, 3.88, 0.02, and 6.41 mmol/g, respectively. An increase in the N content from Fe3O4 to Fe3O4@Cu2(OH)3NO3 was due to the presence of nitrate groups. The addition of H3BTC and the subsequent reaction led to a reduced N content in Fe3O4/HKUST-1. At last, the addition of 1-aminoethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate IL led to an increased N content of 6.41 mmol/g, which is equivalent to 2.14 mmol/g IL loading.

The thermal property of the material was studied by thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) under N2 flow; the results of Fe3O4, HKUST-1, and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 are shown in . As expected, Fe3O4 showed great thermal stability, and no significant weight loss was seen up to 800 °C. In the case of HKUST-1, the first weight loss was seen continuously from room temperature to 150 °C, which could be attributed to the loss of water, including the water inside and outside the pores of HKUST-1. A similar weight loss between room temperature to 150 °C was also observed in IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1; however, the ratio of the lost weight was much lesser than HKUST-1, because the initial water molecules were replaced by IL. The second significant weight loss step that started at around 350 °C was probably assigned to the collapse of the HKUST-1 frameworks due to the decomposition of organic components.

The magnetic properties of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were measured by a MPMS magnetometer. It is clear from the room-temperature magnetization curves of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 () that the corresponding saturation magnetizations of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were 49 emu/g and 38 emu/g, respectively. Despite the lower saturation magnetization, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 was readily collected with a magnet from solution (inset of ); this property allows it to be a recyclable and magnetically functionalized catalyst.

Catalytic Performance

The catalytic performance of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 in the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides with CO2 (1.3 MPa) was investigated in solvent-free conditions. The cycloaddition reaction did not proceed in the absence of catalyst (, entry 1). Furthermore, Fe3O4 or HKUST-1 was also found to be inactive toward the cycloaddition reaction (entries 2–3). In contrast, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 4) showed an excellent performance in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide; 94% yield was obtained after 2 h at 120 °C under 1.3 MPa CO2. Under the same conditions, the IL alone showed a lower yield of 61% (entry 5). Generally, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 showed better catalytic performance than IL. In the case of epichlorohydrin, the product yield was 88% with IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 6); a lower yield (42%) was obtained with IL (entry 7). Similarly, when epibromohydrin was tested, the corresponding cyclic carbonate was obtained in 82% yield with IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 8) and 40% with IL (entry 9). Experiments were also tested under lower pressure of CO2 (0.1 MPa); a longer reaction time 24 h was required to obtain similar yield (entry 4–9). It is also worth noting magnetic separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture could be easily carried out and reused without significant loss of activity for the cyclization transformation ().

The magnetic properties of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were measured by a MPMS magnetometer. It is clear from the room-temperature magnetization curves of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 () that the corresponding saturation magnetizations of Fe3O4@HKUST-1 and IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 were 49 emu/g and 38 emu/g, respectively. Despite the lower saturation magnetization, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 was readily collected with a magnet from solution (inset of ); this property allows it to be a recyclable and magnetically functionalized catalyst.

Catalytic Performance

The catalytic performance of IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 in the cycloaddition reaction of epoxides with CO2 (1.3 MPa) was investigated in solvent-free conditions. The cycloaddition reaction did not proceed in the absence of catalyst (, entry 1). Furthermore, Fe3O4 or HKUST-1 was also found to be inactive toward the cycloaddition reaction (entries 2-3). In contrast, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 4) showed an excellent performance in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 with propylene oxide; 94% yield was obtained after 2 h at 120 °C under 1.3 MPa CO2. Under the same conditions, the IL alone showed a lower yield of 61% (entry 5). Generally, IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 showed better catalytic performance than IL. In the case of epichlorohydrin, the product yield was 88% with IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 6); a lower yield (42%) was obtained with IL (entry 7). Similarly, when epibromohydrin was tested, the corresponding cyclic carbonate was obtained in 82% yield with IL/Fe3O4@HKUST-1 (entry 8) and 40% with IL (entry 9). Experiments were also tested under lower pressure of CO2 (0.1 MPa); a longer reaction time 24 h was required to obtain similar yield (entry 4-9). It is also worth noting magnetic separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture could be easily carried out and reused without significant loss of activity for the cyclization transformation ().
